hello this is chef john from food wishes

this recipe is the perfect example of
how you can take two totally

significantly and by significantly I

only is this gonna be a little more

it's also gonna be a lot better for you

we're gonna take some bok choy and we're
gonna prep it with the old divide and
conquer system so we're gonna go ahead
and cut that just about in half right
where the stalks become leaves and I'm
gonna trim a little bit of that bottom
off and that should liberate all those
stalks and then the prep this part all
we're gonna do is cut it into like
1-inch pieces but we're gonna angle the
knife a little bit which is gonna make
it look a little nicer plus give us a
little more surface area which we
generally want to maximize so we'll go
through and we'll cut those as shown and
the whole strategy here is we're gonna
cut up these stalks and cook those with
the rice and then when that's almost
done we'll add the leaves at the end so
that both parts of the bok choy are
cooked to their maximum deliciousness by
the way I'm just doing a small batch
here you can totally scale this recipe
up as much as you want so we're gonna
prep those stalks I want to put them
into some water to rinse them off this
stuff can be a little gray so make sure
you wash it off and at that point we can
move on to the leaves which are very
easy to do because all we're gonna do is
cut across like this and then once those
are sliced I like to turn the knife give
it a couple cuts the other way so
basically I guess a large chop and
obviously those leaves have also been
rinsed and then all we need to do is
reserve that until the end of the
cooking time all right and then next up
we're gonna start our rice so we're
gonna put a small but heavy bottom pot
down on medium-high heat with some cold
water in it we're to go ahead and dump
in our long grain rice along with a
little bit of soy sauce and by the way
please check the blog post you guys are
putting way too much water in your rice
but anyway we're gonna give that a stir
and we're gonna wait for that to come up
to a simmer and as soon as it does let's
give it one more stir and then dump in
our bok choy stalks and we'll kind of
nestle that down in with our spoon and
as soon as that stuff's been distributed
nicely we're going to cover that title
turn the heat down to low and let that
cook undisturbed for 18 minutes exactly
and what's gonna happen when that timer
rings were now uncover it and it should
look something like that and we are
ready for the final phase of flavoring
so I drizzle in a little bit of toasted
sesame oil I'm also gonna heat this up a
little bit with some sambal which as you
know is just a spicy ground chili sauce
and then last but not least we will
throw in our chopped bok choy leaves and
we'll stir those in but not with a spoon
oh no use the tips also known as the
tines of a fork so get in there and give
it a good stir een make sure
everything's mixed evenly and then and
only then we're gonna turn off the heat
or to cover this tightly and we're gonna
let it sit there for five minutes
undisturbed don't peek and in those five
minutes all those flavors are gonna meld
together those bok choy leaves are gonna
wilt slightly and that rice is gonna
finish cooking perfectly and then once
that five minutes elapses we're gonna
remove the lid and we're gonna give it
what's called the final fluffing so
we're gonna give it another stir with
the fork as you can see right there that
rice is perfectly cooked those grains
are all separate but they do have a very
very thin sticky coating so they kind of
want to grab onto each other but not
really so for me that's the perfect
texture for a long grain rice side dish
like this and of course at this point
you're gonna taste and adjust the
seasonings to your liking
